March 29, 1944.

Mr. F. Matters, Indian Agent, Chapleau, Ont.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, enclosing requisition for materials required for the proposed Constance Lake Indian Day School.

We have submitted these requisitions to the Purchasing Branch and purchase order is being issued today.

I wish you would get in touch immediately with the George Taylor Hardware Company, Hearst, Ontario, and advise them that the purchase order will reach them shortly. I note from your letter that they are prepared to store the goods until they are required, but as we are paying for the material from the appropriation for the fiscal year 1943-44, it would be absolutely necessary for us to have the account dated not later than March 31, 1944. Please note these instructions particularly. The account should reach us some time previous to the 20th of April, as we are allowed to pay from the old appropriation until that date, but, as just stated, the account must be dated previous to March 31.

We have reviewed your letter very carefully and enclose a rough sketch of the proposed building. You will notice that this sketch is suggestive, but I believe will be sufficient to convey to you the idea that we have in mind.

You will notice that we are providing an entrance for wood, material etc. into the basement by means of a ramp. This opening should be wide enough to provide space for the entry of fuel and other material of greater bulk that might be stored in the basement.
You will also note that in the sketch four windows are indicated. These might easily be regrouped in pairs, in order to provide more lighting. On one side, however, we believe it would be better if half windows were used high from the floor, in order to prevent any cross light and at the same time provide sufficient lighting for the room. This would also permit blackboard space below these half windows.

The door might be on the opposite side from that indicated in the sketch, if you think such a position would better suit local conditions. You should provide as much window space as possible in the basement, in order to allow daylight to enter. No windows should be put in the wall opposite the front door.

I note that you suggest 2 x 4 wall studding and, in order that the purchase order might not be complicated and delay us, we have ordered this. However, it is our idea that it would be preferable to use 2 x 6 studding, in order to give better support to the roof. This size of studding is especially necessary, as there will be no sheeting on the interior of the walls. Our suggestion might entail some additional expense, but would, I believe, greatly strengthen the building. As regards the Gyplap sheeting for the outside wall, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that this article has very little bracing power. Personally we prefer diagonal sheeting. This latter sheeting could be covered with asbestos shingles which would make the building more fireproof than it would be if the other method were followed and, besides, would make the building more rigid. It would be appreciated if you would let us have your comments on these suggestions.

In the event of our suggestions being followed, we would have to change the 2 x 4 studding to 2 x 6 studding. However, do not take this matter up with the George Taylor Hardware Company at the present time, as it can be adjusted later, and, in the case of any additional expense, we can have necessary authority obtained from the Purchasing Branch before the erection of the building commences.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
The Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Your letter 65-7-1, March 29th.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter as above, needless to say I was glad that you were able to get the purchase order through in time. I am attaching a copy of my letter to the George Taylor Hardware Co. regarding the invoicing of the material.

Thanks for the sketch, it gives me a much more complete picture of the type of building that you have in mind, and when construction begins I will see that your ideas are carried out.

I think that the windows as laid out in the sketch ought to be increased to six, which would give us approximately 18' X 5' of window space on one side, and this with the same number of smaller windows, high up and staggered as to location on the opposite wall should provide enough lighting; these might be covered with blinds during the teaching period if it were found that the cross light was hard on the eyes of the children, also I think that the small windows should be of the transom type, so that they could be opened to give ventilation.

It might have been as well had you changed the requisition to read 2 X 6 instead of 2 X 4, at the price given for the former size, as I found it necessary to mention the possible change in my letter to the George Taylor Hardware, also about the outside sheeting, as it was quite possible that they would proceed to accumulate the material and then find that they had some that we did not need. dry out and create draft spots, however if the building is to be insulated and asbestos siding shingles applied with a good lap allowed, then there would be no objection to lumber and no chance of any draft getting through, and the diagonal method of sheeting would be much better.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 29th, file 65-7-1, with attached copy of a letter from the Rev. M. Stanley Elliott, of Nakina, Ont. regarding the advisability of opening a school at Aroland, Ont.

In reply I wish to say that I have made enquiries every year at Treaty payments at this point, regarding the advisability of opening a temporary school in one of the old Aroland Logging Co. buildings. I have also discussed with the Indians at great length the advisability of sending their children to residential schools. Unfortunately, several years ago three children died at Fort William during the time they were attending residential school. The Indians were very much concerned and refused to send their children to a residential school since that time.

During Treaty payments this year, I stayed an extra day to discuss the school question thoroughly with these Indians and I wish to report that after a very careful survey only nine children would actually remain at Aroland, to attend school, if the Department opened one at this point. I have no guarantee that the nine would actually attend as some of the parents stated that they might go trapping.

These Indians are typical bush Indians, living the Indian mode of life and derive their living by hunting and trapping, and they take their families to their trap lines and move from place to place continually. Under these circumstances I do not think I would be justified in having the Department open a temporary school at this point.

In conclusion.............(over)
In conclusion, may I point out that there are several fairly large Indian settlements, where the Indians do not reside on Indian reserves along the main line of the Can. National Railways; namely; Aroland, Ombabika, Tashota, Collins, Savant Lake, Armstrong and Allanwater.

I have got in touch, several times, with Father Couture and Father Rolland, in connection with trying to persuade these Indians to move to a reservation where permanent work could be secured for them and where they would be able to send their children to school, but unfortunately we could not persuade them to move, and the missionaries tell me it is impossible to do very much with this type of Indian. However, I do think some action should be taken regarding schooling for these children after the present War is over.

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re; Constance Lake School.

In company with Mr. Arneil I visited the new reserve at Constance Lake a few days ago, and went over the proposed site with him, this has been decided upon, in such a position that we will be able to lay out the village around it and the other principal buildings.

In view of the fact that it has not been possible to have the reserve surveyed, and thus build the road first, and the large number of children who are now at Calstock without any educational facilities, we thought it best that the building of the school should be proceeded with as soon as possible and that the cement basement as planned be omitted, as this would be a very slow and expensive proposition to freight the material to the site without a road, the balance of the material could be taken by a small scow across the lake.

We also saw Mr. Larsen, who is the only contractor available in the district, who has a good reputation for sound work, and who would be able to start work about August 15th., he was not willing to give us a price for the job complete, would only take it on a day labour plan; with the labour available and the rate to be paid, which was $1.00 per hour for Mr. Larsen, scaled down to .45¢ per hour for some of the Indian labourers, the cost would be approximately $2,000.

If you agree to the plan to proceed without the basement, and I cannot see any other way to get the school in operation this fall, will you make the amount available so that I can pay them every two weeks as the work proceeds, we also got a promise from Mr. Perry of Arrowland Lumber Co. to rent us his Bulldozer to clear the site, this ought to take about two days.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: File S-65, Pagwa River

Several other questions regarding trapping and relief were discussed and explained to their satisfaction.

After the meeting was closed I began paying Treaty as I wanted to be all through by noon the following day to catch the train East; to have missed it would have meant another four days at Pagwa River.

Most of the Indians present came for their money, but 26 heads of families or single persons either appeared at the pay table and refused their money or else did not appear at all. George Paris was among those who did not appear at the table, Simeon Taylor #39, Joseph Natawabin #70 and Gaulis Reuben #72 appeared and even after I had explained they they did not have to leave Pagwa River if they did not wish to do so, and that the acceptance of their money would not make any difference to what happened at Constance Lake, that they would still get every consideration from the Department wherever they lived, still refused to accept their money and left it on the table. I had Constable Spencer attest on the roll to this effect.

They did not know why they would not accept it under the new Band and number, the stock reply being "We do not want to have anything to do with Calstock", and unless I listed them under their old Band and numbers they were not interested. I showed them that this could not be done as the Band lists were our only method of keeping account of them. I had the Chief and interpreter show them on my books where Indians had been paid by cheque, so that if it happened that I did not get to Pagwa any other year it could easily be sent to them, but to no avail.

I was very patient with them, and spent the rest of the day and part of the next morning in paying the rest of those present and left for Calstock at 3:30 p.m., feeling satisfied that I had done everything in my power.

(over)
to convince them that no coercion was being used at all.

Regarding relief I checked and found that several old people were in very poor circumstances and had not been getting the full ration as authorized, and although some were among those who refused their money I advised the manager of the Hudson's Bay Store that I would write him and send a list of the goods to be supplied to them in future, through the interpreter I learned that some of the old people were afraid to accept the money as they had been told by George Faries or his friends not to do so, I would classify him as a pretty much of a local bully.

This whole situation appears to emanate from one of two sources, either Mr. Ericson, a C.N.R. section man who also runs a store, a pool room and deals in furs, or the manager of the Hudson's Bay Co., I rather think it is the former, as I learn that he had written a letter to Archdeacon Woodall of South Porcupine, complaining that the Rev. N.R. Clarke was trying to force the Indians to go to Calstock, which is not true, he may have advised them but he is not in the position to attempt to force them to go.

Neither of the telegrams you received were drawn up or written by George Faries, who speaks poor English and I am given to understand cannot read at all. I think it would be worth while to get the original messages which will be on file at the C.N.R. Office at Pagwa and to find out by a comparison of handwriting who is creating the unrest, if the matter was handed over the R.C.M.P. they could and I'm sure would find the culprit, as I am perfectly satisfied that it is the work of one of the above, or both, as if the Indians move they will lose their business.

With regard to the night letter of June 19th, Faries is wrong in his statement that they would not be paid unless they promised to move to Calstock, I stressed the opposite all the time, they could have but would not accept the Treaty money except under their own terms which were impossible, Mr. Arneil can verify that last year the great majority of those present were in favour of Calstock.
and still are, but not so many of these men were present this year as they waited until I went there/to pay treaty, I expect to go up with Mr. Arneil when he visits the agency about the end of July or early in August.

I think this matter will settle itself as soon as we get the school established at Constance Lake reserve, and when the Indians find that they will be much better off there than at Pagwa River, in the meantime unless there is a very great change in opinion among them I would strongly suggest that no other effort be made to pay them Treaty money this year, they having had the chance but refused to accept it, and that the proposed action by the R.C.M.P. be proceeded with.

F. Matters,
Indian Agent.

LED BY THEIR CHIEF, over 100 Cree Indian families moved to their new home at Constance Lake, near Calstock, where their children go to their first school. Here one boy happily draws a house on blackboard.

WEARING INDIAN COSTUME, Albert Yaenkaert, a lumberman, visits the Constance lake settlement to instruct the young braves how to use tools. He is teaching Jim Charles and Matthew Sutherland, all sons of the chief.

CHRISTMAS has come for the first time to these Cree Indian boys from James Bay. Moved with their tribe to a new settlement near Calstock, they are taught carols by the wife of the overseer, Mrs. J. Blackburn.

CHIEF ABRAHAM SUTHERLAND, who left the wilderness of James Bay with his tribe for the new reservation near Calstock, plays Santa Claus for his daughter, Ruby. J. Blackburn joins in the fun.

AGENCY'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING MARCH 31st, 1946.

Welfare & Training:

During March the Public Schools inspector for the district was in Chapleau and inspected the Chapleau Residential school. I have not got his report on the class room work, but he appeared to be very well pleased with the school and children; the former gave him the impression of being well run, and the children were clean, bright and healthy.

The Day Schools at Mattagami and Constance Lake are operating well, and I hope that we will be able to keep the same teachers next year; they are both interested in their work, the children have been good in their attendance.

There is not quite so much work in the district as formerly, due to seasonal slackness in the railroad and lumber industries, but as far as I know all the able bodied men are still working or out trapping; the Muskrat season is open now, but the weather is very much against a good season, as it is impossible to travel due to the ice conditions.

I was very sorry to see that the above letter had been sent direct to Rev. J. Blackburn instead of to myself, as, knowing the man and the work he has done for this last few years it is adding insult to injury.

He holds his B.A. certificate and was qualified and did teach in one of the universities, as is shown on his application, he has worked every summer since going to Constance Lake reserve without any pay from the department at all, and is doing so now, doing general welfare work among the families on the reserve.

His wife, Mrs. Blackburn, has been holding sewing classes for both the school girls and the older women on the reserve without even thinking of asking for any remuneration.

It is fair to say that throughout the year that between them they put in as much time doing welfare work as the ordinary teacher puts in in the classroom, as every day or night there is someone around who is sick or in trouble.

These people left a town where there was every convenience to go into this work, going to an isolated point where there is no convenience at all, neither light, water or other white company, they are two miles from a telephone and whenever anyone is sick on the reserve have to go out to phone the Doctor, in the wintet time this is quite a job.

When Mr. Blackburn went to the reserve none of the children understood a word of English, ans since then he has made wonderful progress with them, he is
able to talk to them in their own language, which is a far greater asset than any teaching certificate, without this progress would have been very slow.

He did write asking that he be allowed to take up the course by correspondence, but when I last saw him he had not had any reply, actually I think this would be a waste of his time, he only has a few more years to teach before he is 65 and I think we ought to use him to the full whilst he is available and pay him a reasonable salary for the work he is doing.

It was my understanding that these changes were intended to help such cases as this, and I do hope that not too much weight is given to holding of certain certificates and too little to practical experience.

I suggested in my recommendation that you speak to Mr. Arneil about this case before passing on it, and I would appreciate if you would see him and do whatever you possibly can in view of the circumstances, his appointment as a Welfare teacher Grade 1, would simply give him about the same salary for 12 months work as he now receives for 10.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.

Education

Although the Constance Lake School got away to a poor start this Fall there are 25 pupils in attendance and except for illness, the attendance is quite regular. In some phases of work, Mr. Thomson the new teacher, does not measure up to the Blackburns. This is most noticeable and understandable when visiting the Indian homes, which are not up to the standards of cleanliness etc. which were previously maintained. On the other hand he has instituted several ideas of which I heartily approve. One is the encouragement of a weekly dance in the school-house complete with lunch, which is supplied by the Indians themselves. Especially among the younger men on this Reserve, this weekly dance has very definitely cut down on the drinking which was being done both on the reserve and in the neighbouring village. The young men themselves told me on my last trip that now that they were able to enjoy this special event each week they did not feel the need of looking elsewhere for entertainment. He is also strenuously organizing boy's sports and under his supervision an outdoor rink has been built and is being maintained and he is attempting to teach the rudiments of hockey.

Reverend Sir:

I have for answer your letter of February 17th and regret that your pay has not yet been received.

However, I find that we wrote to Mr. Whitney on October 25th and sent him the usual forms for completion by you. As these have never been received here, no action has been taken to make payment to you for teaching duties at this school. I am again writing to Mr. Whitney today and have asked him to write directly to you in Toronto concerning this matter.

With regard to the questions raised in the second paragraph of your letter, we are now endeavouring to secure only the services of certificated teachers for our Indian Day Schools. Re: Agent's report on Constance Lake School.

The academic progress of the children attending this school seems fairly good.

While at the school I examined work books, and listened to reading of all grades. I found their writing quite good, and mathematics and reading good, this latter in spite of the fact that these children are exceptionally shy.

Classroom deportment was quite good and the pupils carried out the teachers instructions readily and cheerfully.

The school building was not clean and it was quite cold. The teacher does not put himself out to do janitor work, which, he feels he "does not get paid for". As a result of this the chores are allotted to the older boys and girls and are carried out with little or no supervision. For instance, the fire is allowed to go out at night so that the school is cold until noon hour the next day and the children have to work with their hats and coats on.

In spite of the fact that I had Mr. Larsen build storm porches on both entrances to the school, the doors are continually left open at night, causing
damage to the doors and floors of the school room.

The teacher is not punctual in attending classes, often sleeping until nine a.m., and as a result the children have no incentive to be punctual themselves.

The conditions of the toilets are deplorable and, in spite of repeated directions from myself and Miss Jane Bartlett, our nurse, they show no improvement from my last visit in December.

As you can see from above, the attitude of the teacher toward the property over which he is supposed to have supervision is very careless.

J. L. Whitney,
Superintendent,

Mr. W.S. Makinson,

Dear Sir:

You will recall our previous correspondence in September concerning a position in one of our Indian schools. At that time we did not have a suitable vacancy but I believe we may have one at Christmas which might be of interest to you.

This is a rather isolated reserve and we would prefer a married man with his wife. However, I note that you state in your application form that you have two dependents. Would they be going with you to the school or would you be on your own?

This school is in Ontario and is in the Chapleau district.

Unfortunately your starting salary would be low, due to the fact you do not hold a teaching certificate. However, I believe that we can make representations for you to attend two summer sessions in Toronto and this would work for your teaching certificate.

If you are interested in further details please do not hesitate to write me at once.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,

September 18th, 1944

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Constance Lake School.

I have just returned from an inspection and paying trip to the above school building. I found that fairly good progress had been made; the walls are now sheeted, the rafters on for the roof and the sub floor in.

The carpenters had ran short of material for sheeting the roof, and were going to do another small job for a matter of three days whilst more material was got to the site. I was assured that this would be delivered two days after I left, so expect that further progress is being made.

A start was made with a cottage for the teacher, the cedar posts being in ready for the beams. It will be necessary to complete this, as although the Arrow Land and Logging Co. will provide him with temporary accommodation, they will not be able to do so for all the winter.

I have asked the contractor to let me have a list of the material required for a four roomed bungalow, 24 ft by 24, will it be necessary for me to forward a requisition to get this material, or can an appropriation be made to cover the cost on the same prices and basis as we are paying for the school material, it will be of similar construction.

Now that the roof is being put on all the other material is being shipped, so that we should not have any further delays.

We will need some means of heating the school, and I would recommend that two wood burning

Over.
heaters be used for this purpose, I will look up the types best suited and will forward a requisition to cover.

I understand that Mr. Blackburn is bringing all his own furniture except for the kitchen stove and heater; I presume that these will be supplied by the department as was done at Mattagami, and will also requisition these in a day or so.

Mr. Blackburn has sent me a further list of supplies needed for the classroom and I am attaching requisition to cover them; he asked for some Manual training outfits, but I think these may be left until the project is under way.

I fully expect that the school will be all finished by the middle of October and if we get the supplies in the classes can start immediately.

October 31st. 1944

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re; Constance Lake School;

I visited this building last on Oct. 26th., and found work progressing steadily, it had been slowed up due to some of the material being late in arriving, but good progress is being made.

Roughly the work to be done yet consists of applying the Asbestos shingles on the outside of both the school and the cottage, also the hardwood floors are to be laid in both places, painting and the building of outside toilets will just about finish the job.

Both buildings are solidly constructed according to the plans, and Mr. Larsen is doing a very thorough job, and when finished we will have a solid building which will be quite warm.

In connection with the heating, although the circulator type of heater is better in theory, the practical experience is that the upper part of the rooms are warm, but the floors and lower part cold, for instance the Arrow Land Co. have installed a circulator type heater in their office, it is an oil burner and of a large size, yet when I was there last week the men were complaining of the cold office, when they come in wet they cannot get near the heat, having had some experience with these in the past was the reason I requested the regular wood heater.

I have instructed Mr. Blackburn to install the circulator heater on arrival, but I think it will be necessary to locate another regular camp heater, will you have the Purchasing Branch try the Adam Hall Co., who specialize in this type of material.

Over.
At the present time I have about $250.00 left of the sum allocated for the building of the school, to cover the rest of the building and the painting I estimate that another $400.00 will be needed, can you arrange to have this forwarded to me, before November 8th, which will be the next pay day.

I took the liberty of ordering the necessary stove pipes for the school and cottage heaters and stoves, so that they could be installed on arrival, the stove and heater for the cottage arrived the day I was at Calstock, these pipes are to be 28 gauge galvanized iron; the ordinary stove pipes being too flimsy to be safe.

On the return from my next visit I expect to be able to report that one building is finished and the other almost so.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.

P.S. Due to the lateness of the season for building houses on the reserve, a lot of the families have left, but I have a good number of applications for lots to be taken up in the spring.

Nov. 13th. 1944

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re; File 65-7-5
Letter Nov. 9th. 1944

This will acknowledge receipt of the above letter regarding the material for the Constance Lake School.

There were several changes in the material specified on the first Purchase order, it was decided verbally when I was in Ottawa to use the Johns Manville Asbestos siding for the outside of the school, this was done and there is a difference in the price of this article as against clapboard, it makes a much better finish, is permanent and does not need painting every year or two and is fireproof, any clapboard we would get today would be of a doubtful quality, besides this we had to get more lumber, applying the sheeting diagonally tends to more waste, but will be much stronger, door sets and other hardware, also lumber to build a shed which is being used as a store room, and living quarters for the carpenters at the present time, but which is being left intact for use as a store room in the future, it will have to be moved later on.

We did not get the amount of cement required for the proposed basement, only a small quantity and some lime for the building of the chimneys.

At the start this was a rough list intended to charge part of the cost up to the last fiscal year, I proceeded on the assumption that we had a credit balance of $3,008.89 set up with Taylor Hardware, and have drawn material against this as required, with the intention of striking a balance when the job was finished and forwarding an account for the difference.

When in Hearst a few days ago, I checked with the George Taylor Hardware to get an estimate of how it was going to come out, I find that our total account for both the School and the house will amount to about
$4,500., against this I have purchase orders to the amount of $4,056.71.

The Taylor company do not mind which way the account is put through, but which way would be most satisfactory to the Treasury Branch; either submitting the accounts as per the purchase orders; or putting through a set of invoices of the goods actually delivered to the site, in a larger amount than that authorised.

Possibly I should have applied for each extra item as it was required, but that would have meant a series of delays, and I followed out what I think was the only practical way to get the work done in the quickest time at the least cost.

Please let me know in which manner you would like the accounts submitted, and I will arrange to have this done by the hardware company.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Constance Lake School.

When I made my last inspection at the above school on November 9th, I took some photographs of the School, Teachers residence and of the two combined, of which I am attaching a print of each.

The residence was completed on Nov. 16th and is now being used by the teacher; at the time that the picture was taken the opposite side of the school building was finished, and since then the work inside has proceeded, also outside toilets have been built, and steps built on both the school and house.

When these are completed are think we will have a very good set of buildings, the centre building shown in the full view of the site, is a shed that has been used for storage and sleeping quarters for the workmen.

EX'D.

Mr. F. Matters, Indian Agent, Chapleau, Ont.

I have your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing photographs of the school and teacher's residence at Constance Lake. The Department was very pleased to receive these and the buildings appear to be very serviceable.

In looking at the pictures it would appear that to limit the fire hazard it would be desirable to cut down a number of additional trees, in order to leave as open a space as possible around the new buildings. Possibly you could arrange to have this done during the present winter.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Chapleau Ontario
December 7th, 1944

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re; Constance Lake School;

I visited the above school on December 5th., and found that work has been suspended for the winter, the inside of the school is finished, and the first classes were called for December 6th.

This last week the children have been in attendance but helping to unpack and prepare the school for teaching.

The outside is not quite finished, as the Asbestos shingles had not all arrived, and about 11 squares are yet to be applied, this will not affect the heating of the building for this winter, and classes will be able to carry on.

Whilst waiting for these to arrive, and I was definitely advised by the George Taylor Hardware Co. that they had been shipped on November 8th, the carpenters had built the outside toilets (3), and finished off anything else that was to be done with the exception of cupboards.

I find that I will need $38.18 to complete the payment of the carpenters, and unemployment insurance stamps, this will balance the account as to the advances made and the amounts paid out.

I would also recommend that 3 cupboards be procured, or at least 2 cupboards and 1 set of open shelves, the latter and one cupboard for the school supplies, and the other for the storing of medical supplies.

Mr. Larsen, who has been the carpenter at the school, offered to build these at a price of $115.00 for material and labour, they will 6 feet high, one six feet wide.
wide and the others 5 feet 6 inches and four feet six inches wide respectively.

If this is in order, and some are certainly needed, will you kindly authorise me to have them made.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.

Gentlemen;-

Dear Sir:

Attached you will find all the receipts for transportation that we are able to secure.

On many occasions other goods than for your account would be shipped to Hearst in the same Express or Freight shipment, and only your portion of express or freight would be charged to you. Therefore the express or freight receipts would not be of use to you as they would not correspond with the amount charged you.

In regards to transportation by truck from Hearst to Calstock the same also applies, as we hire our delivering done by the month, and charge you only for the actual time it takes to deliver materials.

I am sorry we are unable to give you exactly what you require, but due to Mr. Smiley leaving and a new party taking over, it took some time for Mr. Philbin to become familiar with the details. I believe you will have no trouble with any future invoices. We would appreciate it if you would rush our invoices through for payment as soon as possible.

We are enclosing Credit Note for one only Caulking Gun, $7.05, as it has since been returned and charged to the Contractor, who is keeping it.

In regards to difference in price of Cedar Grain Shingles, the ones priced at $14.50 had to be secured from a company in Southern Ontario, and we had to pay them resale price plus L.C.L. Freight. The shingles secured in that way were the only shingles available in Ontario to complete
your job. The manufacturer was sold out. One of the 11 square lots is still on hand at our Hearst Warehouse, being held there as your contractor was unable to complete the job before the freeze-up. As they were brought in especially for this job, we felt it only right that we should invoice you and hold them in stock, to be taken by you in the spring.

We thank you for the reference you make in the second last paragraph of your letter, and appreciate that you realize there were many obstacles which prevented us giving you the service we would have liked, but war makes many things impossible. We consider ourselves fortunate to be able to carry on business as well as we are doing after five years of war.

I am looking forward to meeting you some time soon, and wish to thank you for the consideration given to us.

Yours very truly,

THE GEORGE TAYLOR HARDWARE LTD.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

Re: Purchase Orders 27133 and 23309.

The above purchase orders were issued in connection with repairs and improvements to the school and teacher's residence at the Constance Lake School. The total of these two purchase orders was $3,374.71, plus transportation of the goods ordered.

We are now in receipt of the attached account, certified by Indian Agent Matters, and this amounts to $4,932.61, which includes the transportation costs. Mr. Matters points out that owing to conditions existing at the present time it was necessary to make several changes in the type and quantities of the materials purchased. As a consequence, the items shown on the account do not exactly coincide with the items shown on the purchase orders.

When the buildings were nearing completion, it was found that extra work had to be done, and, as labour was available at that time, the Agent secured the materials necessary. As a result, the amount expended for material has exceeded the total of the two purchase orders already issued.

Reports received show that we have two good buildings, namely a school and teacher's residence, at this point, and Indian Agent Matters, who has had considerable experience in building, has certified that

P.t.o.
all the materials secured were absolutely essential and purchase of them could not be avoided if the buildings were to be properly completed.

Under the circumstances, it would be appreciated if you would issue an additional purchase order for $1,162.42. I would appreciate also receiving from you a memorandum which we can present to the Representative of the Treasury, permitting payment of the account, even though the items on the accounts are not exactly similar to those appearing on the purchase order.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

With reference to Mr. Crowley's memorandum to you, dated April 20, in connection with the expenditure at the Constance Lake School, I submit the following explanation:

Constance Lake is a new reserve, to which we were moving a number of Indians, and one of the promises made to them was that educational facilities would be provided immediately. With the approval of the Minister's office, we endeavoured to ascertain if tenders could be obtained for the erection of the building. However, Indian Agent Matters, who is well acquainted in that part of the country, advised us that the only contractor available in the district was Mr. Larsen, who had a good reputation for sound work. Mr. Larsen was not willing to give a tender on the work complete but offered to supervise the work and work himself on a day labour basis, with the understanding that the Department would purchase the material.

In preparing the original plan for the school, we arranged to erect the building in such a manner that eventually it could be used for a council hall or recreation centre for the adults and children on the reserve and consequently made no arrangements for living quarters for the teacher to be attached to the building to be used as a school. After commencing the work, it was brought to our attention that a teacher's residence was necessary if we hoped to obtain a teacher. Consequently, for the expenditure incurred we have actually two buildings—one used for school purposes and the other as a residence for the teacher. Attached to this memorandum are three
pictures. No. 1 shows the building used for school purposes; No. 2 shows the building erected as a teacher's residence and No. 3 shows the location of both the school building and the teacher's residence. The building in the centre was a temporary building erected as store-room and sleeping quarters for the workmen. It was later moved to another portion of the reserve. The expenditure incurred covered the cost of the labour and materials required for the buildings shown in the pictures attached.

Acting Director.

Encl.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re; Painting Calstock School.

The above school was not painted when the building was completed last year, due to the lateness of the season, and wanting to open the school as soon as possible.

The paint is there ready to apply, and on my last inspection trip with Mr. Arneil we thought it best to try to get the work done before school re-opens next month, so advised Mr. Blackburn to get two of the Indians to start work painting under his supervision, all the inside has to be painted and the outside trim.

I trust you will approve of this, as it was necessary to get the men started whilst the road work was stopped, later they will all be employed on the road building job, Mr. Arneil will confirm this on his return.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, 10 December 1946.

Mr. F. Matters, Indian Agent,
CHAPLEAU, Ontario.

In reporting on his inspection of the Constance Lake School on Nov. 6th, Inspector Blanchard writes as follows:

"The building which is being used as a school seems to be quite adequate. Natural lighting is definitely poor, but this cannot be helped. It is hoped that the new school will be built just as soon as possible."

We realize that the building used for school purposes will at some later date be used for a community hall. However, we thought that the present building was quite adequate. Apparently the Inspector considers the lighting insufficient. We would appreciate having your comments on the Inspector's remarks.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: File 65-7-5 (WT-1), Letter Dec. 10/46.

This will acknowledge receipt of the above letter regarding the Constance Lake Day School.

I would say that the building itself is quite adequate. The natural lighting, although not very good according to the present school lighting standards, is still sufficient and ought to be considered as such for some years yet, as it is not projected to build a new school until the Reserve has been much further developed.

During the winter time and with snow on the ground the building is quite bright inside, and the inspector did arrive there this year before the snow. The building is recognized as being one of the best in the district as compared with other white schools. I do not think that the Inspector really expects us to proceed with the building of a new school for some time, but is more or less pointing out that some day it will be necessary.

Yours very truly,

F. Matters,
Indian Agent.
Chapleau, Ont.,
Feb. 11th/47.

Col. B. F. Neary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Col. Neary:

During our conversation in Toronto, you requested that I try to procure a picture giving a better view of the Constance Lake Day School. I am enclosing some that I have just secured which I think will give you a better idea of the building, also of the inside showing some of the pupils.

You also suggested that you would like to get a plan of a one room school with accommodation for the teacher under the one roof. I asked Mr. Larson for some suggestions along this line, as he drew the plans for all the Constance Lake Buildings. I am enclosing three rough plans and if you would like further construction details on any one of them, please return and I will get a more detailed plan for you.

I have received the Special Permit from the Provincial Department for the taking of fur-bearing animals by the children of the Chapleau Residential School under the direction of the Principal, so I expect to have the scheme operating for the muskrat season this year.

I am writing this to you personally so that you will be sure of getting the pictures and if there is anything further with which I could help you, please let me know.

Yours very truly,

F. Matters

Re: Furniture in teacher's cottage
Constance Lake Reserve

The furniture in the above noted cottage is the property of the Rev. Jos. Blackburn. Mr. Blackburn is leaving Constance Lake to take up duties in Folyet at the end of August.

When in Constance Lake last week Mr. Blackburn advised me that the house to which he is going in Folyet is furnished and that he would not need to take any of his furniture with him. North Simiskinng 25 March 1907

Mr Scott, Indian Department Commissioner

Dear Sir,

Last summer I had the favor to meet your honor and at Obition. Then you talked to me about this question of having a summer Indian school.

I have considered this matter and at your request I think I can do something for it. But considering that these Indian children don't understand a word of English, I think it would be convenient to have last summer a teacher who could talk both languages in and English, in order to get a start to the little ones. I hope to be able to find this person.

Please then, let me know if this question will arise, and what wages of our department intend to give.

I go up at the end of May, or beginning of June.

If I can do some more part-time opening of this Indian school I will do it with determination.

Yours truly,

J. Evans, Jr.
Missionary
Ottawa, March 30, 1807.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to Father Ewain's application for a summer school at Abitibi I beg to say that I think that such a school is the only one suitable for these Indians, as they disperse in the fall for their winter hunt.

According to the census there should be over thirty children of school age, and if the Priest can secure a teacher and any place to hold the school, I would recommend that the Department should allow a grant of $150 for the summer's work. The school could be kept open for about five months. This is the amount of the grant the Department is making to the Temagami and Nepigon summer schools.

A small supply of school material could be sent to the Priest, and I would suggest that the selection of a teacher be left to him.

The Secretary:

When recently at Fort Abitibi I paid a visit to the school at that place and found 42 children in attendance under the tuition of Mrs. Simpson.

The children showed that they were receiving considerable benefit from the instruction given them, Mrs. Simpson inculcating habits of cleanliness as well as teaching them to read and write.

A number of the children were examined as to their proficiency in their studies and showed that they are making creditable progress.

A portion of the church had been used for school purposes and it would not be advisable to make any other arrangements at present as there is reason for believing that the trading posts will be removed shortly to some point near the line of railway. North Temiskaming, Sept. 13th 1910

To the Superintendent,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I take the liberty to call your attention to the fact that the Abitibi School of which I am Teacher is situated over a hundred miles from North Temiskaming, the place of my residence. So, the expenses to go up there and come back are very heavy.

Last spring I thought it would be better to go via Matane by railway and steamboat. But owing to the irregularity of the steamboat from Matane to Abitibi it took one six days instead of three, so that the expenses were still greater. Going by clock's road the expenses are $25.00 going up, and the same for coming back, so that it gives a total of $50.00 for travelling only. The least I pay for board at Abitibi is $0.60 a day, so that for 30 days it amounts to $45.00. Then I have only $50.00 left for three months' work. I think it would be only fair for the Department to add at least...
$50.00 to my salary amounting presently to $150.00 for three months' teaching.

I know that teachers in the same district who receive the same salary than I, and who have not the least expenses to make to reach their school, beside having much less pupils than I have.

This year 67 children have attended school, and I think a salary of £200.00 for three months would not be too much for such a number of pupils, even if there were no other reasons for it.

Four months' teaching, as the Department professed it last year, would be useless. The Indians being hardly able to remain three months at the pay. When it comes to the third month, most of them leave, and it would be too cold to begin before June or to stay longer than to the end of May.

Once more I beg the Department to consider this matter fairly.

Trusting you will understand the justice of my appeal and grant my humble request.

I remain Sir,

Yours truly,
Mrs. R. Gibbon

Madam,

I have to inform you that the Chief and Councillor of the Abitibi Band called at the Department today and complained that some of your pupils, who are grown up young men over the school age, are damaging the church in which the school is held and the Chief and Councillor claim that they are a nuisance and should be dismissed from the school.

The Department is of the opinion that these young men should try and obtain work during the coming summer, but if they wish to attend school for the purpose of receiving an education there is no objection to their doing so, so long as they behave themselves, and they should only be there during school hours. The Department would like you to inform these young men that this concession is made on the understanding that they behave themselves while in school and it will expect reports from you from time to time as to the manner in which they conduct themselves.

Re Indian Schools

To the Superintendent,

I am greatly interested in the summer schools kept in my missions, specially those of Abitibi and Timagami, where I could verify the good order, the devotion and the practical capacity of the directing teachers; I take the liberty to ask that those teachers be granted an increase in salary.

It is impossible for a woman like Mrs. Donald McLaren who has travelled from Abitibi to North Temiscaming with five young children to live with a salary of $50.00 per month; it is at least the double which she requires, considering furthermore that her activity and devotion to teach the band of Abitibi is above elogy. I have ascertained this during the full month of June which I spent as missionary at Abitibi.

I have just spent 10 days at Timagami, and I found the same earnestness with Miss El. Honam who keeps the school at Bear Island. This person teaches only five months, and has naturally her year spoiled. I recommend therefore the same salary of $100.00 per month for this teacher. In making these recommendations I am only answering to these devoted person's request, who begged me to intercede in their favor, I am doing this with greater pleasure knowing their merit.

Yours very humbly

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a communication from the Rev. Father Evan, informing us that it will be no longer possible to hold the summer school for Indian children at Abitibi in the church. Sir:

In reply to official letter No.35-2-1 of the 6th inst., I beg to report that I do not consider the attendance at the Abitibi Summer school would warrant the expenditure that would be incurred by the erection of a school building. My experience is that the Indians stay around the Post during the visit of the missionary in the month of June, and until the distribution of the Treaty nine annuity is made, and as soon as that is over they depart, with few exceptions, and camp along the rivers adjacent to the N.T.C.Rly. until the hunting season commences.

I have found a large attendance at the school during my visits to the Abitibi Post this past two summers, in the month of June, but I know that after my departure, the attendance dwindled down to a very small number.

In connection with this matter I also beg to report that as none of these Abitibi Indian children are able to speak any English, it is absolutely essential that the teacher be able to talk Indian, and it is a difficult matter to obtain the services of a teacher able to speak the language, that possesses sufficient qualifications to be able to teach the children very much.

Father is the missionary to these Indians it is essential that he should approve of the teachers that are appointed for these schools, but he really knows very little about the qualifications of any of those who are able to teach school in this vicinity as he has been away from here for a number of years, and very rarely visits here. Next year the terms of office of the present chief will expire at Thomas Rupert's House, and the Department is kindly informed Mr. Cass to be present with authority to hold the election of a new chief.

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 360 days in each year.

Schools shall be closed for Christmas holidays from December 25th to January 1st, unless this date falls on a Sunday.

The winter term will commence on January 2nd and end on June 30th in each year.

The following holidays will be allowed during the year: All Saturdays, Labour Day, all Federal, Provincial, Native, Municipal, or Premiers' Days, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year's Day, Easter Monday, Victoria Day, and any other holidays which may be declared by the Board of Education.

In calculating school attendance, the Board of Education will allow for holidays, limited number of days of sickness, and for which payment of salary is made. In the case of teachers who are employed for more than nine months, the Board of Education will allow for the first three weeks of sickness, but no charges are to be made without the written consent of the teacher.

The marking session begins at 8 o'clock and ends at 12 noon, and the afternoon session from 1 pm. to 4 pm., with a recess during the period of 12 noon to 1 pm.

In computing salaries for sickness periods, teachers will be paid in the proportion that the number of days they have worked bears to the total number of working days in the pay period.

Salaries of teachers will be payable quarterly, except in cases where the teacher has been employed for less than nine months, in which case the salary will be paid monthly.

In cases where the school is closed for more than five days, the teacher will be paid for the remaining quarter with such additional pay as may be necessary.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 200 days in each year.

Schools shall be opened after the summer holidays on January 1 unless this date should be Labor Day, and shall close for Christmas holidays on December 22.

The winter term will commence on January 6, and end on June 30 in each year.

The following holidays will be observed during the school year: New Year's Day, Valentine's Day, Good Friday, Easter Monday, Victoria Day, Dominion Day, Thanksgiving Day, Labour Day, all Provincial Holidays, and the following Federal Holidays: Easter Monday and Victoria Day.

In addition to the above, the Bank Holiday in each month will be observed as a limited number of holy days of obligation, and the salary will be allowed.

During the summer months the school will be closed for the following holidays: Memorial Day, Canada Day, and the following Federal Holidays: Labour Day, Thanksgiving Day, and the following Federal Holidays: Easter Monday and Victoria Day.

In the event of the school being closed during the summer months, the teacher will be paid at the end of the school year—i.e., school is regularly taught—three months.

Summer holidays are not taken into account in payment of yearly salaries. Each school year begins and ends on the first of July, and the school will be closed for a change in the holiday periods.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

All questions relating to the day school should be referred to the local Indian Agent.

8. When, owing to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not long enough to contain all the names, use another form, paging it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one, to it.
9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.

Mr. North Simiskinway, 7th July 1907

To the Secretary of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

I have the pleasure to announce to you that the abitibi school is doing first class. I am just arriving from this post, where I have resided for a month. I left here with the teacher, Mr. Simpson, on the 23rd May; we had a hard time to go up: snow, ice, and rain. The school has been opened this 5th of June.

When I left, a week ago, over 60 Indians children were attending at school. The Indians are pleased and proud about this school and the teacher who is succeeding very well. But I tell you she will not make very big wages, because the expenses have been very high.

I am now following the expenses myself according your agreement, for supplying the school. I give myself the word, keep it clean as my own expense. Remember the lumber is very dear, so try to save every thing the cheapest way possible.

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

I observe that our little church at Abitibi is so much in request that I am under necessity of rebuilding a new one. The Indians are prepared to assist me in building at the same place, where they will still come for many years. As you are aware, this church is used for the summer school for the Indian children, who number this morning 55, and there are still 12 families to come. I am prepared to furnish again the new church and to set up seats and desks for the school; but I am in need of assistance from the Department for that purpose. I should, therefore, ask for the sum of $300 from the Department, and should make an agreement with it to furnish the school-room while it remains, which will be much less expensive than the one at Timagami that the Department has built and which is much smaller than the one required by the number of children at Abitibi. The church that I am going to build, 60 X 26, will cost me at least $1500. Please, therefore, reply to me immediately, because I shall have to do special work in view of the school.

Sir:

On my arrival at the Abitibi Mission with Miss M. A. McDonald, as teacher, I noticed that several of the most necessary articles for the pupils were missing. I took the liberty of purchasing myself, inclosed herewith you will find the small account for two dollars and twenty-two ($2.22) cents.

Today I have already counted forty-four (44) pupils in the class. Miss McDonald is excellent and she is very well liked by the parents and pupils.

I hope everything will be alright.

Kindly send at once the following articles which are absolutely necessary for the Summer and which is impossible to purchase here.

Yours, et.
Ottawa, June 21, 1923.

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 13th instant, I beg to say that a cheque for $2.22 in payment of the articles purchased by you will be forwarded under separate cover.

We are ordering from the Government Stationery Office forty-eight readers, two yards of slated blackboard cloth, a box of chalk and seventy-two lead pencils.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

EXTRACT FROM RIGHT REV. JOHN G. ANDERSON, BISHOP OF MOOSONEE, COCHRANE, DATED APRIL 6, 1932.

I wish to advise you that the Rev. Reginald A. Joselyn will take up his duties at St. Paul's Mission, Albany, James Bay, in succession to Rev. P. A. Northam, on or about May 1st, next. He will take up the duties of the day school as well as dispenser of medicine.

Mr. Joselyn has been here with me since November, studying the Cree language and is doing well. He is to be married in Toronto on the 23rd instant, and will return here with his bride on way to Pagwa.
Ottawa, May 4, 1932.

Right Rev. Sir:

With reference to that portion of Your Lordship's letter of the 6th ultimo, informing the Department that Rev. Reginald A. Joselyn will take up duties as teacher of St. Paul's Mission, Albany, James Bay, on or about the first instant, to succeed Rev. P. A. Northam, I have to say that the appointment of Mr. Joselyn is approved. The grant allowed towards salary of Mr. Joselyn will be at the same rate as was paid in the case of Mr. Northam, viz., $450 per teaching year, less 10 percent for the current fiscal year.

It is hoped that Mr. Joselyn will meet with every success in his work at Albany.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKensie,
Secretary.

Right Rev. J. G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moosonee,
Cochrane, Ont.

Feb 7th 1936

The Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

The Royal Trust Company inform me that they have received no cheques from you in payment of the salary of Rev. R.A. Jovelyn, teacher of the Albacore School, for the March, June and December quarters of 1935. Mr. Jovelyn has advised me that he has sent in the returns for the quarters mentioned regularly to Mr. Eyers, your agent at Moose Factory, but only the cheque for Sept. 1935 has been received by the Royal Trust Company. If this be true, then it would appear that Mr. Eyers has been negligent in forwarding cheques to you. Mr. Jovelyn tells me that he is sending duplicates to Mr. Eyers, I trust that this matter will be adjusted soon as it causes me much inconvenience.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

C.E. School at Albany.

The Church Missionary Society School at Albany is not what could be termed a substantial building, it is old and the foundation is considerably decayed. Its dimensions are 26 x 16 ft. 6 in. x 14 ft. high, with gabled and shingled roof. Gable 8 ft. high and side ridge of rafters 11 feet, which gives 429 square feet of floor space and 6632 cubic feet of air space.

The equipment of this school in the matter of desks and seats is very inadequate. There is no ventilation, excepting that caused by the stove which heats the building. There is no drainage in connection with it. The water supply for this institution, as is also the case in regard to the hospital and school at the Roman Catholic Mission here, is procured from the Albany river, and is admitted to be quite healthy.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir,

Since my connection with the above Mission, I have experienced in my school work here, that the school building is far too small for the number of children attending.

The building was erected about 20 years ago, and at that time, and up to about 14 years ago was large enough for the number of children attending. The size of the school house is 27' x 17' feet. Enclose particulars which I think will be useful to the Dept in giving their kind attention to my appeal for a larger School.

I shall be very pleased to give the Dept any further particulars which they may require.

Ottawa, March 20, 1914.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th ultimo stating that the Albany Mission School building is not large enough to accommodate the present attendance, which has more than doubled in the last four years, and asking for a larger school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will be glad to have further particulars in regard to this application, which should contain full information as to what is required. It would be next to impossible to send in building material and it is considered that a substantial log structure could be put up which would meet all the requirements until better facilities for transport are available.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

John T. Griffin, Esq.,
Albany Mission (C.E.) School,
Fort Albany,
James Bay, Ont.
Particulars for Proposed New Day School
St. Paul's Mission
Church of England

The building to be of logs, weather-boarded outside with 3/4 in boards and painted white, etc., the inside to be 41 feet in length by 24 feet in width, walls to be 11 feet high ceiling and ventilated. Building proper to be used on the inside and outside between the boards and logs, no windows on the side, blackboard on north east, west end of floor, 7 ft by 3 ft on south end, 3 windows by 6 ft each east and west, porch and door, etc., floor to be raised about 5 ft over ground account of floods at the break of the river. Roof to be galvanized Eastlake shingles, small turret on building, storm windows, cannon wood stove 3 ft with piping, bands, wire, flange pipe for roof, building to be painted on the inside, etc., for school books, etc., hat and coat hooks extra, chair & desk for teacher.

John J. Giffin

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of March 20th and in reply I have much pleasure in enclosing you rough plans and particulars for the proposed new school in connection with this Mission for the Indian children of the Albany band. Logs can be rafted down the Albany River a short distance from here and squared at this place. Sawn lumber, doors & windows can be had from the Hudson Bay Co. saw mills at Moose and freighted here by their steamer. Our Mission will see to the erection etc.

Yours truly,
John T. Griffin
Missionary, Albany

To the Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of September 25th & in reply, I wish to say that the Department is labouring under a heavy delusion in saying that it is their opinion that the present building will serve the purpose for the Anglican Indian Children at Albany.

Please study the enclosed list showing the average attendance for the past 10 years since I took charge, & please note that the size of the School is 25½ feet by 16 ft., does the Dept think that the cubic measurement is correct for each child? For the past year I have had of necessity to hold two Schools one in the morning & another in the afternoon so that we may have room to move about. I drew attention to this state of affairs & at the beginning of the
late War the Department took up the matter with me and asked for particulars of our requirements; this was sent & is now in the Dept. His Lordship Bishop Anderson took up the matter also with the Dept & if I do not mistake, the Dept promised to do something after the war was over. I have been faithful to the Dept as a School Teacher since 1906 & ask for a more encouraging letter from the Dept. I wish also to state regarding the present state of our school that it requires a new roof, door or new foundation, the building is only a frame structure & is not suitable now for the number of children attending. I trust the Dept will agree with me that the school according to its size is not large enough for the number of children attending. Trusting that your Dept will give this matter their earnest consideration.

I remain Dear Sir,

Yours Sincerely,

J.H. Griffin
Missionary in Charge

Ottawa, October 14, 1920.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant in further reference to your request for the erection of a new school building at St. Paul's Mission, Fort Albany, and furnishing a statement showing the school attendance for the past five years.

In reply I beg to say that, as the present building is built on mission property and is, therefore, the property of the church authorities, this Department could not undertake to have any repairs made to the roof and foundation.

With reference to the erection of a larger building I beg to say that, if a new school were erected, it would require to be built near where the Indians reside and, as the reserve is some distance from the present school and the Indians do not live there, the Department cannot undertake the erection of a building on property which it does not own. If the church authorities will arrange for the erection of a new building large enough to accommodate the Indian children who will attend, the Department will then consider the question of providing an increase in the grant now allowed for salary.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report of Treaty 9 payments to Indians of James Bay District for 1926.

Education.

At Fort Hope and other points I was unable to see the day schools in session. At Albany, Mr. Northam is busy erecting a new day school, which is located about one hundred yards from the bank of the Moose River.

Sir:-

Your Department very kindly consented to make a Grant of money towards the cost of a new school house at this Mission for the use of the Indians of the Albany Band. I beg therefore to enclose the financial statement of monies expended to date on the erection of the new school building.

The schoolhouse is forty feet in length,and twenty feet wide.These measurements do not include the porch which is eight feet by six feet. The whole is built on a solid foundation of heavy logs,squared to a thickness of ten inches,and standing two feet six inches above the ground. The foundation logs and floor sleepers are covered with a heavy coating of Stockholm tar. This particular style of foundation is at present the only possible kind at Fort Albany owing to the nature of the land which is wet and marshy. The building here is subject to continual heaving caused by the severity of the frost in the winter,and a very gradual thawing out in the warmer months of the year. Cement is much too costly for it would have to be freighted in by the river transport,which freight is very expensive. The wall of the school,from the top of the foundation to the eaves,are eleven feet. The frame of the building is of 2 in.by6 in.scantling spaced two feet apart.The walls outside are sheeted with inch lumber,B.C.Fir,and the joints between the boards are caulked. This is covered with a ply of heavy tar paper,over which is a ply of good quality spruce Cove Siding,tongue and groove. The roof is half pitch,the rafters and sheathing being of B.C.Fir,which is covered with Eastlake Galvanized Shingles. There is a fire proof chimney.The flooring is of 1/2 inch spruce lumber,tongued and grooved.The inside walls are covered with a good quality spruce V joint lumber,as is also the ceiling. The schoolroom is nine feet in height from floor to ceiling.The windows are on the south side and are three triple windows,each separate window having 3 upper and 3 lower sash,or nine upper and nine lower sash in all,with a total of 189 glass lights. The ventilation is good as all the lower sash can be raised and all the upper sash lowered. There is a small teachers room for school supplies,also containing a window. The porch is lighted by a window.The schoolroom is furnished with a large Carron stove and has accommodation for sixty pupils.

In addition there is an upper story above the main room,lituated four feet below,while portion is not finished but when extra accommodation is needed it will be possible to make out of it a room forty feet in length,and about 14 feet wide,with walls four feet at the sides and rising to a height of eight feet in the centre.

The outside of the building has been painted with two coats of white paint,and the usual trimmings black.The galvanized shingles are painted a ferric red.The inside ceiling is painted with two coats of white paint,and the inside walls will be painted with two coats of paint as soon as the weather becomes a little milder.

A drain has been dug on two sides of the school lot over which culverts have been placed. Two outside lavatories are in the course of construction.

I would particularly draw your attention to the fact that over Six hundred dollars of the total cost of the building to date has been paid in river freight alone to the two Trading
Companies for the necessary building materials which had to be brought in by the river route from Pagwa River Stn. to Albany, distance of 300 miles. The extra river freight has added to the cost of the building to that extent.

The amount which we ventured to ask your Department for in the first place was a Thousand Dollars. The Paying Officer of Treaty No.9 told me that not all that amount was granted. As this school has been built and will be maintained solely for the use of the Indians of the Albany Band I venture to trust that your Department will deals as generously as possible in the assistance you give us financially.

May I ask that when the Grant is paid the cheque may be made out and sent to The Rt.Rev.J.G.Anderson,D.D., Bishopthorpe, Cochrane, Ont. His Lordship very kindly advanced the necessary monies expended in the building.

I am, Sir,

Your's v.truly,

Mr. Perrier:

In my report to the Department I referred to the new day-school that had been constructed by the English Church at Albany. This building is now completed. The building is on a heavy foundation. At the same time I cannot agree with your last statement "that in future no rental payments will be allowed at this school." If the Department had paid the full cost of the school that would be just and fair. I sent you a statement in Feb. last certified by our missionary Rev. P. A. Northam showing that up to that time about $700 had been expended on the school, and a number of seats and the painting of the interior had still to be done, which will raise the cost to fully $1000. So that it appears to me that at least half its rental formerly paid should be allowed for the upkeep of the building. If the Department pay the full cost of school buildings in Ontario, Western Reserve and have salaries ranging about $800 or $900 why should we be treated differently in Ontario especially in places like Albany so far removed from railways? I trust that you will re-consider your decision and allow us some consideration for rent etc.

Yours sincerely,

John G. Anderson

Diocese of Moosonee

Doctor Stone,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I have examined all the children at the Ang.Res.School here and find all but two in healthy condition.

Emma Cheechoo has T.B. of the middle ear on both sides but seems to be improving as there is no discharge at present but some odor. If you think she should not be kept in the school will you notify me.

Daniel Sack has some fibrousés in the apex of both lungs but there is nothing active, he is not gaining in weight.

Two of the children I sent to the hospital in Cochrane a month ago, I believe they both have T.B. I have heard indirectly that they are both still running temperatures. I will see them when I pass through Cochrane on June 7th.

The sanitation of the school is much improved but the condition of the whole building is very bad, of course this is a very old building and unless this school is replaced in a very few years it will have to be closed, the foundations have all gone and the building is beginning to slant at a noticeable angle.

Yours truly,

W.L.Tyrer M.B.

Alderville, Ont., March 24th

Dear Sir,

I am under obligation to make a payment of money in Toronto on April 1st, and if it would not be asking too much, I would be deeply grateful if my salary for the past quarter (just ending) could be forwarded to me at the earliest possible date.

The Dept for some time past has been good enough to send a bonus cheque in addition to the regular salary. This cheque is usually sent later than the salary cheque, and as it comes to the Agent, some delay is occasioned. This usually doesn't make any difference; but just now, as I will need all the money I can muster by April 1st, I would be glad if it could be sent direct to me, when the salary cheque is sent.

The school report for the quarter is made out and will be sent to you by current mail.

Thanking you in anticipation of this favour.

Yours sincerely,

Frank J. Joblin.

Ottawa, August 1st, 1929.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, with reference to the application of Miss Dorcas Atkinson, of Roseneath, for the position as teacher of the Alnwick Indian Day School at Alderville.

In reply I beg to say, in view of your recommendation, the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Atkinson, to begin duties when the school reopens after the present summer holidays, on September 3rd, next. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $95 per teaching month. Please inform Miss Atkinson of her appointment, and ascertain from her whether she will accept the position or not and be prepared to commence duties on the date mentioned, and you should inform the Department accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. J. Slade, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, October 29, 1929.

Sir:

With reference to the salary of Miss D. Atkinson, teacher of the Alnwick Indian Day School, it is regretted that through oversight her cheque for $95 was forwarded to the Treasurer of the United Church of Canada, Toronto. This was done owing to the fact that Rev. Mr. Wilding's salary had been sent in this manner. I am arranging to have Miss Atkinson's money forwarded to her at once, and in future her salary cheques will be forwarded to her direct.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 29, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

On the 21st instant, cheque No. 4304 for $95 covering the September salary of Miss D. Atkinson, teacher of the Alnwick Indian Day School, was issued in favour of the Treasurer of the United Church of Canada and sent to you. In issuing the cheque, the Department overlooked the fact that Miss Atkinson's salary should be paid direct. I would appreciate if you would immediately issue a cheque for $95 in favour of Miss Atkinson and forward it to Mr. F. J. Slade, Indian Agent, Fenella, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sirs:

Department cheque for $65.00 - No. 4304 -
in payment of September salary at the Alnwick School at
Alderville came to hand a few days ago. It is returned
herewith, as the status of this school has recently
changed; the teacher, who also carried on mission work
among the Indians at that point, having been moved to
Moraviantown during the past summer to conduct a similar
work there, for which the Department is paying $65.00 per
teaching month. For the present, at least, the minister
residing at Rosenesth will look after the mission work,
and I understand the teacher of the Indian Day School at
Alnwick will be paid direct by the Department.

Yours sincerely,

Reverend Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 29th instant, regarding salary payments to Miss Dorcas Atkinson, teacher of the Alnwick Indian Day School, I beg to say that the following cheques have been forwarded to her since the first of the current year:

Sir,

I enclose herewith a resolution passed by the Alnwick Indians in General Council held on Monday last asking that a well be dug for the use of the Indian School in the School Yard. I beg to say that at present the well on the Mission Property adjoining the school yard is dry and has been for a long time and the well at the mission house is nearly dry at present so that the children are at times much in need of drinking water. Heretofore there has always been enough water in the mission well to supply the school when the other well was dry. The well will cost $1.50 per foot for the first 20 feet and $1.60 per foot after up to 40 feet I think that plenty of water will be reached at 40 feet. In stating costs I mean digging well draining stones etc and finding everything. A platform will cost three or four dollars and a pump about $16.00. What shall be done in the matter? I am sure that the Indians residing in the centre of the village will make use of the said well and pump and of course use up the pump much quicker that it otherwise would be used.

Yours Truly,
