Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 25th instant, re cost pump in the well at the Indian School at Alderville I have to say that when I wrote you on the 3rd day of October last I stated that I thought that water would be reached at forty feet, but I was mistaken and the well was dug over fifty seven feet deep; and of course I meant that the pump would cost about $16.00 if the well was only 40 feet deep. I could have got a wood pump for less money than the one I bought, but at a general meeting of the male members of the Band held on the 29th ultimo I asked the Indians what kind of a pump they wanted, when a vote was taken and nearly every member voted that the superior pump be purchased; and there was a large number present. I therefore got the pump they wanted, and I am sure that they made a good choice.

It only cost a trifle more than a wood pump would have done, and I think that it is worth nearly twice as much. I told you when I wrote you that the well would cost $1.50 per foot for the first 20 feet $1.60 per foot for the second 20 feet etc., but owing to the late season and the strong competition we got it dug for $71.66 at my estimate the well would have cost $87.65 so that on the whole the well and pump cost much less than the estimate.

Your Obedient Servant

[Signature]

D. G. of I.
Ottawa Ont.

Roseneath, 23rd November, 1905.

Sir,

Re seats for the Alnwick Indian School I have to say that I wrote to Inspector Odell about the same and enclose his letter therewith. You will see that he prefers individual seats and I think that they are very much better than double seats. We will want say 24 seats (single) which I think will be ample at all times for this school but in case there should be a rush at any time one or two of the old seats might be used for a short time by not putting too many seats in the school room there would be more room on the floor. Mr. Odell thinks that the manufacturers could tell what sizes I mean heights the seats should be, say that the children would average from 7 to 16 years of age. Mr. Odell says that the School Furniture Co. at Preston Ont. make good seats etc.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

We will get a stove for the school at once as one is very much needed.

J. W.

Sir,

I enclose herewith account for repairing the chimneys on the School house and Church at Alderville. In your letter of the 26th day of August you instructed me to have this matter attended to immediately but I could not get any person to do the work until recently. The building was high and we could not get an Indian to attend to Mr. Simpson and Mr. Eley came near being killed, yesterday he sliped and was going down the roof on his back and just as he was going over the eaves he caught one of the posts on which one of the scaffolds was built had he fallen to the ground he would have been dashed to pieces. I think the Simpson charged a very good price for his work but he would not take less.

Your obedient servant

S. D. of I. A.
Ottawa Cnt.

P. S. The chimney on the church was in a very bad state indeed and the church might have got burned at any time.

Dear Sir,

I beg to report that we have not sufficient seating capacity for the pupils of Alderville Indian Day School. At present there is need of room for ten pupils.

There seats on platforms, on which the room when it is very dark, and beside and behind stove within 1 foot distance. When the cooler days come the pupils cannot sit inside the hot stove.

Invaluable plan of classroom. I would suggest the partitions be removed so fire danger should they be done we shall acquire more room to move new seats. I am doubtful of the present box stove could heat the larger room.

Would it be possible to have one of officials visit school and see first hand our condition. At any rate we will need accommodation immediately as every available space is occupied and still there is desire to follow.

OTTAWA, October 12th, 1921.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Mr. Fred J. Dodson, teacher of the Algonquin Indian Day School, in which he requests that the class room be enlarged by removing the partition between the ante-room and the class room, and the providing of a dozen more desks, and also, if this is done, that a larger stove be provided.

I will be pleased if you will furnish your views regarding this request. You should state whether it would be advisable to remove the partition and enlarge the class room, and, if so, the cost of having the work done. You should also state if the ante-room is taken into the class room what provision would be required to provide cloak room space for the children. Before the Department can decide the matter a report giving full information is required.

This teacher is being informed that his request has been referred to you.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. R. Coyle, Esq.,
R. R. #1, Hastings,
Ont.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th inst., regarding the removing of the partition between the living-room and the classroom in the Alnwick Indian Day School in order to provide more classroom accommodation and furnishing an estimate of the cost of having this work done.

In reply I beg to say that you may take the necessary steps to have these alterations carried out, and you should make arrangements possible to have the work performed at the least possible cost. It is noted that the estimate which you furnished for the labour and materials is approximately $50.00. In addition, that this partition be removed except about 8 feet on one side of the room which is to be enclosed to take in the new accommodation.

As soon as this work has been completed, you should submit certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the amount charged.

It is necessary to purchase any material for the work, and competitive prices should first be obtained.

Regarding the school desks required to provide the additional accommodation, I beg to say that you should state how many desks at present in the school and also whether they are single or double, and the sizes of the extra desks required. Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I wish, thru the Agent Gayle, to draw your attention to a possible improvement in the heating of our Day School.

The building is of brick with a large hall over hick. We are using a box stove to heat it. The floor is always cold. The teacher complains. The floor is always cold. The teacher complains. The floor is always cold. The teacher complains.

There are 47 children enrolled. Average last quarter was 34.

When the building was put up there was a large excavation made and land held at about 5 or 6 ft. deep. There is a good stone foundation well under building. There are 3 chimneys on building from foundation.

I would respectfully suggest that a pipeless furnace be put in for next winter. The approximate cost (including installations) would be $175. The building is good for another forty or fifty years. Wood is becoming scarce in this locality. Coal will be the fuel within ten years.

The furnace would heat the hall also, thus saving fuel and labor.

Memorandum,

Mr. McLean.

While at the Alnwick Reserve I had occasion to visit the school and my attention was drawn by the teacher to the condition of the blackboard. This board is made of 3" boards with, of course, a series of cracks and it makes it very difficult indeed to work upon.

I would recommend that a new hylo-plate be supplied, one 16'x3', and two 10'6" x3'.

He replied by letter dated June 19th that he was writing to a number of different firms and that he would forward their quotations for this work as soon as he received same. On the 30th June he stated as follows: "Wrote H. Lambert, Hastings, Ont.; W. L. Allen Company, Cobourg; Peterborough Hardware Company, Peterborough, and the Hamilton Stove and Heater Company, Hamilton." He inclosed replied which he received.

Allen & Company stated that they did not handle furnaces. The Peterborough Company in letter to Mr. Agent Coyle dated June 23rd stated that they were turning over the enquiry to Messrs. W. R. Turner & Son, Peterborough. No reply was received from H. Lambert, Hastings. The Hamilton Stove and Heater Company offered to furnish and set up a wood furnace complete and install registers for the sum of $387.00.

As the above were the only quotations received, we authorized our agent by official letter of July 17th to give the contract to the Hamilton Stove and Heater Company.

We had a communication from Mr. W. R. Turner, Peterborough, dated July 26th, in which he stated that he had mailed a tender to our agent on the 21st instant.

It will be noted that the date on which he mailed this tender was four days later than our letter of instructions to the agent to award the contract to the Hamilton Stove and Heater Company. The cost of the installation of this heating system for the school and council chamber will be paid from the interest fund at the credit of the Mississaugas of Alnwick Band. We have wired the Agent to hold the contract if it has not yet been let and to report.

A Pipeless Wood Furnace!

FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN DISTRICTS WHERE WOOD IS STILL THE FUEL ordinarily used, there has, until now, not been a PIPELESS furnace really suited to their requirements. Furnaces advertised to burn either coal or wood are really coal furnaces with a loose wood grate, for which the wood must be cut in small pieces, and in which it is hard to keep a fire over night.

The "HILBORN" PIPELESS FURNACE, on the other hand, HAS A REGULAR WOOD FIRE-BOX WHICH WILL TAKE A STICK FROM TWO TO FOUR AND A HALF FEET LONG, and the fire-box door is big enough to take chunks that otherwise could not be used. THERE IS NO TROUBLE ABOUT KEEPING A FIRE ALL NIGHT IN THE "HILBORN".

THE PRINCIPLE OF THE HILBORN PIPELESS WOOD FURNACE is the same as that of our famous HECLA PIPELESS FURNACE, based on the fact that warm air rises and cold air falls. The cold air is drawn down from the house, through the outer case, into the furnace where it is warmed and goes up into the house again through the centre of the register. With the doors between the rooms left open, this results in a circulation of air throughout the house that warms it in a surprisingly short space of time and keeps it at an even and comfortable temperature.

The HILBORN IS BUILT WITH EITHER THREE OR FIVE DRUMS TO SUIT INDIVIDUAL REQUIREMENTS. These drums are so arranged that the fire travels several times the length of the firebox before reaching the smoke pipe. This long fire travel, combined with the large surface of the drums, and the additional radiating surface of the corrugated firebox, make the HILBORN PIPELESS FURNACE a most POWERFUL AND ECONOMICAL HEATER.

THE CASING is doubly insulated. Inside the Galvanized Iron Casing is a lining of asbestos, and inside that a lining of tin—an added expense that is an economy, because it prevents loss of heat into the cellar.

THE REGISTER, which can be supplied in either oxidized copper or black japanned finish, is of the proper size to give best results. The proportions of both register and casings have been carefully worked out, and are RIGHT.

THERE IS NO RUSH OF HOT, DRY AIR FROM THE HILBORN PIPELESS. The casing and register have been carefully proportioned to give just an easy, steady flow of air at summer heat—and the water pan in the HILBORN is big enough so that in passing through the furnace the air absorbs just the right quantity of moisture to insure a healthy atmosphere in the house.

A COOL CELLAR: The Casing on the HILBORN PIPELESS FURNACE prevents any heat from radiating into the cellar, which as a result is always cool, so that fruit and vegetables may be stored within a few feet of the furnace.

Sir:-

With reference to the contract which has been let for the installation of a heating system in the Alderville Indian Day School, I beg to say that the Department has received a communication from Mr. H. M. Roblin, Brighton, Ont., who is to do the work. He informs us that no arrangements have been made for the excavating of the cellar of the building to the desired depth to allow for the setting up of the furnace.

This furnace cannot be installed until the necessary excavation has been made. The tenders do not call for the contractor to do this work. It will, therefore, be necessary for you to arrange for having an opening cut through the foundation of the building and the cellar excavated to the desired size and depth. A window should be put in where the cellar foundation is cut, in order to provide light in the cellar. A doorway, of sufficient size, should also be cut in the floor of the ante-room of the school room and a door and stairway installed, for the purpose of carrying down the fuel required.

This work should be undertaken by you at once and rushed to completion, in order that the contractor may proceed with the installation of the furnace. You will be good enough to inform the contractor when the excavating is completed, so that he can start work on his contract. You will please see that this work is done with the least possible expenditure and, when completed, properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded.

The contract for the installation of the furnace includes the providing of a suitable concrete foundation on which the furnace shall rest. A copy of the specifications for the installation of the heating system has already been sent you.

We shall expect to hear at an early date that the work which you are now authorized to do, in excavating the cellar and the installation of the heating system has been completed.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 8th inst., I have the honor to state that on the 5th inst., Mr. Dodson drew my attention to the chimney on the Church which is badly out of repair and this very day I wrote to the Chief John Smokey and we made a general inspection of the School grounds and public buildings on the Reserve.

We concluded that if the ground were ploughed and scraped between the Church and School and the earth taken up into the School yard to level up grounds and make a depression between the buildings it would answer the purpose of drainage.

Mr. Dodson was taking that day a Labor Day and the pupils were clearing up the yard.

The Sexton will clean the closets according to Agreement and I have asked him to put on the necessary repairs.

I think the above can be done for approximately $15.00. The chimney on the Church...
Sir,

Should be rebuilt.

I cannot give an estimate until I can get a mechanic to look it over.

I have the authority to get the repair of the mission house and school also. The school painted as soon as possible. The expenditure will cost approximately $150.00. The church shed needs shingles. The old shingles are blowing off with the wind and the plates will soon decay with the rain coming through them.

The Mission Barn where the threshing machine is stored is in a dangerous and dilapidated condition. I fear the roof will fall in any time with a heavy wind.

The building should be torn down and rebuilt before it falls and is damaged.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 7, 1929.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Alnwick Agency, states that a teacher's chair is required for the Alnwick Indian Day School, as the old one is worn out. He also states that the ceiling of the little storeroom has fallen in places and requires new plaster. He further states that the two closets are in very poor condition and past repairing and that two new closets are badly needed.

I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase and delivery of a suitable chair for the teacher's use. No unnecessary expense should be incurred in the purchase of same. You should also arrange to have the repairs required to the plaster of the ceiling of the storeroom carried out, and you should forward certified accounts, in duplicate, covering the above authorized expenditure.

Relative to the erection of new closets, I have to request that you will furnish a report stating the approximate cost of building same and whether you could arrange to have this work carried out before the extreme cold weather sets in. In estimating the cost, you should consider the erection of separate toilets, with proper screened approaches. When we have particulars as to the cost, etc., consideration will then be given to authorizing having the work carried out.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. J. Slade, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fenella, Ont.
Sir,

With reference to the new closets, I have received an estimate on the cost of same. Chas Jones, of Centretown, a good carpenter has agreed to build new ones and put in cement foundations for $10.00 each, out of all new material. The material including hauling the gravel would cost around $55.00.

He says he could build them this fall if you wish.

We could use some lumber of the old ones but believe we can sell them for more as they are than it would save to wreck them. I have arranged to have the plaster repaired, and have ordered the new chair.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean, Esq.

Sir:

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, regarding the cleaning of the interior of the school and closets at the Alnwick Indian Day School.

In this connection I have to say that the janitor should be responsible for the scrubbing and ordinary cleaning of the classroom. Should, however, the woodwork require washing, you may engage the services of an Indian woman to do the work, and you should see that the job is satisfactorily completed.

If there is any extra work in the cleaning of the closets and placing them in a good, sanitary condition, the Department will approve of you arranging with a competent Indian to do the work. It is considered, however, that the ordinary work in keeping the closets clean should be carried out by the janitor as part of his regular duties.

If any extra cleaning is required to either the classroom or closets, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost. These accounts should give full particulars as to the time employed by the person who does the work and the rate paid per hour or per day. Sir,

I visited the Alnwick Agency on the 18th and 19th instant for the purpose of making a general inspection of the agency work and to instruct and assist Mr. Grieve, recently appointed Agent, as found necessary.

The school buildings are in very fair condition. The metal roof is beginning to show signs of rusting. If this is not checked at once it will deteriorate rapidly. There is a special preparation to be had to prevent rusting. The cost is not great and adds years to the life of the metal. I would recommend that the roof be treated this season if possible. The front porch needs a new post and the archway over the entrance should be pointed and a few bricks replaced.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.

Sir:

Enclosed please find Bill and Vouchers in duplicate in favor of Dundas Bros Cobourg, covering Water Fountain, for School Room on Alnwick Indian Reserve.

I may say in connection with this account, that maybe I overstepped my authority regarding this purchase, as the water vessel spoken of was a pail, but after talking the matter over with the teacher, who informed me that a pail was very unsanitary, as the children would dip the cup into the pail and spill a certain amount on the floor, and in many instances, when they did not drink all the water that was in the cup they would empty the balance in the pail again.

I made enquiries regarding other rural schools and find that they nearly all use this kind of water container. It is lined inside leaving an inch of air space which enables the water to remain cool for a longer period. Of course it costs more than a pail but will last for years and probably will be as cheap in the end, trusting this meets with your approval,

With reference to your other letter of the 9th instant, you may have a new lock installed on the door of the supply room at the Alnwick School. It is noted that this will cost approximately $2.25.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. O. Grieve, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Roseneath,
Ont.
